name: NA
htj_2017_2021: Crowded housing (% of occupied housing units), 2017-2021
rbs_2017_2021: Severely rent-burdened (% of renter-occupied housing units), 2017-2021
edb_2017_2021: High school graduation rate (% of residents), 2017-2021
can_2021: Have ever had cancer (% of adults), 2021
lng_2021: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (% of adults), 2021

name: NA
uns_2017_2021: Percent of residents without health insurance (at the time of the survey).
svi_2020: The Social Vulnerability Index was created to help public health officials and emergency response planners identify and map the communities that will most likely need support before, during, and after a hazardous event, such as a natural disaster, disease outbreak, or chemical spill. SVI indicates relative vulnerability by ranking places on 15 social factors, including unemployment, minority status, and disability, and combining the rankings into a single scale from the 0th percentile (lowest vulnerability) to 100th percentile (highest vulnerability).
evr_2018: Percentage of renter-occupied housing units with an eviction over the past year. An eviction happens when a landlord expels people from property he or she owns. Evictions are landlord-initiated involuntary moves that happen to renters. This is based on available eviction records and estimates for missing data, and does not include voluntary move-outs or evictions that take place outside of the legal system. A high eviction rate could be based on a high number of evictions, a very low number of renter-occupied units, or both.
htj_2017_2021: Percent of occupied housing units with more than one occupant per room (e.g. three occupants in a one-bedroom apartment).
rbs_2017_2021: Households spending more than 50% of income on rent are considered severely rent-burdened. Rent costs do not include utilities, insurance, or building fees.
chaixyp_2023: Composite score of cumulative impacts reflecting communities in Chicago most burdened by pollution and most vulnerable to its effects.
lfa_2019: Percent of residents who have low access to food, defined solely by distance: further than 1/2 mile from the nearest supermarket in an urban area, or further than 10 miles in a rural area.
www_2017_2021: Percent of households with any connection to the internet, such as broadband, dial-up, satellite, or a cellular data plan.
edb_2017_2021: Residents 25 or older with at least a high school degree: including GED and any higher education
ede_2017_2021: Residents 25 or older with a four-year college (bachelor's) degree or higher
coied_2015: The education domain of the Child Opportunity Index 2.0 scored as Very Low (5), Low (4), Moderate (3), High (2), and Very High (1)
coihe_2015: The health and environment domain of the Child Opportunity Index 2.0 scored as Very Low (5), Low (4), Moderate (3), High (2), and Very High (1)
coiov_2015: A composite index that captures neighborhood resources and conditions that matter for children's healthy development scored as Very Low (5), Low (4), Moderate (3), High (2), and Very High (1)
coise_2015: The social and economic domain of the Child Opportunity Index 2.0 scored as Very Low (5), Low (4), Moderate (3), High (2), and Very High (1)
ump_2017_2021: Percent of residents 16 and older in the civilian labor force who are actively seeking employment.
pov_2017_2021: Percent of residents in families that are in poverty (below the Federal Poverty Level).
for_2017_2021: Percent of residents who were not U.S. citizens at the time of birth (includes both naturalized citizens and those who are not currently citizens).
leq_2017_2021: Percentage of residents 5 years and older who do not speak English 'very well'.
pct_w_2017_2021: Percent of residents within each demographic group. Use this topic to explore age, gender, and racial/ethnic breakdowns.
can_2021: Percent of resident adults aged 18 and older who report ever having been told by a doctor, nurse, or other health professional that they have cancer (other than skin cancer). Data for counties and states are age-adjusted. Data for zips, tracts and smaller layers are raw.
fai_2020: Percentage of the population experiencing food insecurity at some point. Food insecurity is the household-level economic and social condition of limited or uncertain access to adequate food, as represented in USDA food-security reports. 2020 data is a projection based on 11.5% national unemployment and 16.5% national poverty rate.
lng_2021: Percent of resident adults aged 18 and older who report ever having been told by a doctor, nurse, or other health professional that they have chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), emphysema, or chronic bronchitis. Data for counties and states are age-adjusted. Data for zips, tracts and smaller layers are raw.

name: NA
svi_2020: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) (Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry / Geospatial Research, Analysis, and Services Program)
evr_2018: The Eviction Lab at Princeton University (All yearly data), Cook County Sheriff's Office of Research (Monthly data in Chicago only)
chaixyp_2023: Chicago Department of Environmental Permitting and Inspection
lfa_2019: USDA, Economic Research Service, Food Access Research Atlas (Food Access Research Atlas)
ump_2017_2021: American Community Survey (Tables B23025, B23001, and C23002)
can_2021: Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) (County and state level data), PLACES (Sub-county data (zip codes, tracts))
fai_2020: Map the Meal Gap (Map the Meal Gap 2020)
lng_2021: Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) (County and state level data), PLACES (Sub-county data (zip codes, tracts))
